title: Lola B12/00 and B12/01 Indy Cars
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a 1/24th scale reconstruction of Lola's B12/00 2012 IndyCar proposal.
In 2009, IndyCar finally publicly recognized how ancient their current cars were and opened up bidding for a replacement design for 2012. They accepted bids from 3 established manufacturers and 2 upstarts. Deltawing actually went ahead and unveiled a full-scale model (their idea was the hardest to sell), but the second most detailed proposal was from Lola, who built a computer model for CFD testing as well as a physical scale wind tunnel model. Most of the drawings they released of this design don't quite line up, but I feel like I've captured most of the details. I've added files for the B12/01 road course variant, though there was considerably less reference material so I don't think it looks as accurate. Oh, I should note that the chassis selection story ends with the incumbent Dallara winning and Lola eventually declaring bankruptcy :/
http://www.racecar-engineering.com/articles/features/the-indycars-that-never-were/3/

Pick between the /00 and /01. The wings are interchangeable (/00 are speedway style, /01 are high-downforce), the tubs have some minor differences (floor, roll hoop, fin, mirror placement).
Print one of each part except the wheel pins (4), the Large pins (2), and the Front and Rear wheels (2 each). The tub, wings and steering wheel should be printed with support. There isn't that much support on the tub volume-wise (mine weighed 31g straight out of the printer and 27g after trimming) but removing it is time-consuming, and getting it all out of the footwell is impossible, at least when printing in PLA.
Fitting the wheel pins is also a bit of a challenge, and should be done before fitting the suspension to the car. Point the pin part towards the center hole, then use a rigid thin object against the flat side to push it past all the suspension arms. That might not make any sense, so I've included a picture. I would not recommend actually using a scissor blade for that job, or trying to do it one-handed while holding a camera with the other. Safety first!
Fit the suspension to the car before putting the wheels on.

comments.text:
i printed the tub, then tried to print the front and rear wing, no support will generate in simplify3d so i had no way to print them, after a bit of messing around, i found out how to fix it. I used "repair" and "flip surface orientation".
this seemed to fix the model in S3D and now it recognises the surfaces and places support appropiately.

First of all: All merits and credits and rights and everything else (including ownership of the files) goes to original authors - and reprap community. Second of all: Versions here are the original files, only tweaked for toner transfer purposes. These are some files for DIY pcbs with Toner Transfer, for Mendel.
Images for printing top bottom and silk are all 600 dpi. More info on http://www.reprap.org/wiki/DIY_PCBs_double_sided_toner_transfer

  • image file for ATX / ATX2 voltages takeout + UM232R footprint boards:
    A4 file ready for transfer, 600 dpi. For ATX supply, the board allows access to all voltages without any modifications to the supply. The UM232R i made because it looks better on a proper board.

  • stepper motor driver v3.0 for toner transfer +A4 layout: i never got time around to test this because i jumped to vers 3.3, but should work; nonetheless, use at your own risk

  • stepper motor driver v3.3 for toner transfer: changed smd from 0805 to 1206; increased pcb size and spacings accordingly; some provisions(â€just in caseâ€): 7805 can be fitted with a small to radiator (totally not needed but i like the overkill) and can be moved around abit if needed; smd versions electrolitic capacitors could be fitted (for smd connect the vias nearby with bottom layer); alternative jumpers instead of the dip switch; alternative 0.100â€ pins connectors for motor; 2 opposite diagonal holes for an A3977 radiator (overkill heatsink higly recommended), and some holes underneath A3977 that are just something like chip vent; can use pots with pitch of 5/5mm also (besides 5/2.5mm);
    -the version named Makerbot: has 6 pins idc and no min/max, as it was in the original file;
    -the version named Mendel: has 10 pins idc and .100 min/max of 3 pins each for compatibility with current mendel Gen3 Electronics and specifically Mb v1.2
    I dont think i was inspired in getting the right versions names, but i am always lacking inspiration :))

  • MB 1.2v: A4 file with tqfp pads edited, ready for transfer, 600 dpi: orientation of the board on the file would of been better horizontal, but then wouldnt fit one near the other. Check photo paper shrinkage (on vertical direction) with a real piece of .100 pins along their pads. Use good quality board materials for this one. RepRap modifications included (no longer compatible with other makerbot version): as per http://www.reprap.org/wiki/PCB_adaptions_for_Mendel the bridge near icsp header area, bridge(s) in atx connector area (leading to two traces in bottom layer to be combined on the top area of sd card - looks weird but its ok).

  • added EC 2.2v: A4 file with tqfp pads edited, ready for transfer, 600 dpi. I did my own EC22 with a version that was almost at the size and spacings of the original file, and after doing it like that i decided it needs further spacing out and more severe cleaning up which i did in the file. As a result the images linked and the file are slightly different, and the last version should be better. However be warned, i did not tried this last version in real life myself, although i think it should work: use at your own risk, etc.

Some general instructions, a few pictures and more information here:
http://www.reprap.org/wiki/DIY_PCBs_double_sided_toner_transfer In general about toner transfer and these files, should be safe to say that unless you already have the tools and already know what to do, then you are most probably better off with just buying a commercial set of electronics. If anyone does any parts and has any comments on it i would appreciate posts here at least to let me know if its all right. Or at least so i know if i should bother to keep this up or update it even. Ofc, any further corrections, changes or suggestions are welcomed. Good luck to all. Last update:
  • added thermocouple and thermistor boards, along with some firmware for EC2.2 on the wiki instructions page.

A flexible bracelet you can adapt to your liking, and add your name, or another text, on. For a two color version, see: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:56257
For a full inside version, see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:319183 Update 3.5.2014: fixed the issue with the excessive material in the inner circle

Open it in the customizer. As bracelet stretches, give inner radius so as to sit nicely on your wrist. Set outer radius, set height, and set the text you want on the bracelet, eg a telephone number where you can be reached!.
The text can be in relief, or as holes. When printing relief, make sure you print with 100% infill. Holes still must be tested on a printer, I assume you should print thick and slow so as to not jump over the holes too fast. 
It is important that you give the nozzle diameter of your 3D printer, as this is what will make sure your bracelet does not break easily.  The thickness is one nozzle diameter, if you want the bracelet thicker, set nozzle to 2 or 3 times your real nozzle diameter

comments.text: I'm using Skeinforge to test this out.  SF reports that at 0.4mm layers height, the edge width will be 0.72mm.  Keep in mind that the slicer is not aware of the size of the nozzle.  It is only concerned with the volume of plastic coming out.  I do not know if this is the case with replicatorG.
comments.author: bmcage

comments.text: My printer can't handle 0.4 layer height, ugly things come out with that, so never tried that again. It is strange however that a larger height increases the edge width above the objects width. I would call that a problem with the slicer, as obviously you will not be printing the object as constructed. The solution would be to increase the nozzle size. If you set it to 0.8, the width of the bracelet will be 0.8, the gaps will be larger, and layer height of 0.4 producing 0.72 edges should not be a problem.

title: Eglise de Veneux-Les Sablons pour l'expo in situ Art & Spirituel

description.text:
https://www.facebook.com/cultureveneux
Des Arts au Spirituel…
La Ville de Veneux - Les Sablons a le plaisir de vous inviter à un évènement exceptionnel, en l’église St Philippe et St Jacques, lors des journées européennes du patrimoine, samedi et dimanche prochains, 20 et 21 septembre, de 10h à 19h.
L'église ouvrira grand ses portes à tous les visiteurs pour une exposition-événement dite « in situ », croisant différentes formes d’expressions artistiques, peinture, sculpture, photographie, musique, chant, jonglage, danse. Susciter des résonnances entre les arts, créer des liens entre les artistes locaux et les habitants sont les principales ambitions du projet.
Les artistes plasticiens participants: Martine Alamarguy, Sébastien Babass, Emmanuel Bénard, Anne Biró, Françoise Cluet, Katherine Dara, Geneviève David, Anonyme du XXIème siècle, Pascal Graziani, Martine Hatton, Michel Lenoir, Fred Lorne, Justine Govignon, Florence Moreau, Mireille Pancras, Dominique Perréard, Sylvie Poncelet, Jean-Baptiste Rigail, Cyril Vallée, avec la participation du Père James Prieu.
Bienvenue au vernissage, le samedi, à 18h, avec un spectacle de danse (voir ci-dessous).
Le samedi 20 septembre :
14h, 15h : Requiem de Mozart
Version piano à quatre mains, Pippa Schonbeck et Fernando Geraldes
La Croche Choeur, chorale d’adultes du Conservatoire Accords, direction Fernando Geraldes
16h : La Source, de Hasselmans, puis Cloches sous la neige, Au matin, de Tournier
Bénédicte Rostaing, harpe
16h30 : Ceremony of Carols, de Britten
La Gioia, chœur de femmes, chorale d’adultes du Conservatoire Accords, direction Laure-Marie Meyer
18h : Vernissage
Sarabande de la 5ème suite de Bach, suivie du 1er et 2ème mouvement de la sonate de Kodaly pour violoncelle solo (op 8)
Carole Catelain, danse, Anne-Claude Moquet, violoncelle
Le dimanche 21 septembre :
14h30,15h30 : Divertimento N° 6 de W.A.Mozart, Trio de Devienne, Adagio du Concerto pour clarinette N°5 de Molter, Hommage à St Hadelin, Largo de Haendel et Aria de Bach
Notes Solidaires, musique de chambre, avec Corine Lefevre, flûte, Daniel Gersztenkorn, Pascal Lecuyer, clarinettes, Jacky Borde, basson, clarinette basse et saxophone soprano, Francine Saby, orgue
16h : Des Fraises en Hiver, gospel
17h : « Foi de femmes, femmes de foi », chant sacré de femmes
Eclairs d’arts, Laure-Marie Meyer, Elsa Rousselle, Kate Kaiser
Contacts : Anne Biró [email protected], Dominique Jacquot [email protected]

author: cva

description.text:
A lot of the time, my iPhone ends up being a really expensive flashlight. However, there are some times when you need to have light AND have both hands free. I know this is a revolutionary concept, but please bear with me, as the secrets of the universe are about to be revealed before your very eyes! This clip will let you clip your iPhone 4 or 4s securely to a shirt pocket with the flashlight facing outward, breaking the chains that would normally bind you! It's a miracle of a semi-religious nature, and it can be yours for the low, low price of $0.21-$0.42 of PLA and about an hour of printing.  
As a side benefit, you can also use this clip for recording video, as long as you don't mind the video being shot from nipple level.

Print in at 100% infill with external supports enabled. If you are adventurous, the part can be printed without support. However, on a tall print like this, you really have to make sure that your print bed is sticky and that your printer is well-calibrated to print without supports. I've tried both, and this is a rare case where printing with supports produced a more aesthetically pleasing part without requiring any cleanup.  
If you have bad layer adhesion, you may want to rotate the part so that it prints horizontally. Otherwise, the clip will easily snap under pressure.  You will definitely need supports for that, and you'll spend quite a bit of time whittling away the supports.

This is a holder for cotton diskettes. The cylinder in the middle of the container pushes the diskettes up so that they are always available at the top of the box.

Print the two parts, put the diskettes inside "makeup2", then put "makeup2" inside "makeup1". The dispenser is ready. The file "makeup2b" is 2.6 millimeters shorter than "makeup2", so that the two cylinders are the same height once they are one inside the another. But when the dispenser contains diskettes, 2.6 mm of difference in the cylinders are not visible or somehow important. The photos of my print are "makeup1" and "makeup2b" files. The diskettes stay inside the container, yet they are easy to take, so I'm happy with the measures.
By the way, the diskettes here used are 60 millimeters of diameter. Skeinforge sliced my .stl adding a cover on the central cylinder, as it works anyway, I left it this way. I could consider to make a lid to cover the dispenser, if you think it's a good idea, let me know in your comments, thanks.

author: EVINp97

description.text:
This is my attempt to make a cartoony Narwhal creature. The spike thingy is kind of in the wrong place but I think it is funny looking. 
I made the object using Lightwave 3D version 9.6 and exported the file as an OBJ file without any problem.

I used makerware to make the x3d file using the High Quality setting. I used 5 shells and a 35% infil. You have to use the raft and supports feature to get it to print. This print will take about 4 hours or so at the predetermined size. You have to be careful with the spike because it can become detatched easily; I had to glue it back on with epoxy. BTW, superglue doesn't work with PLA very well. It will harden but it takes forever and the bond is not as good as 5 minute epoxy.

comments.text: I usually subdivide a few times and then run Triple to get OBJ export to get good results.  LW11.5 just came out and it has improved OBJ export specs

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:48136 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=48136

Using the following options: length = 129.9
width = 65.9
height = 11.6

After seeing MakerBlock's blog post yesterday I was inspired.  So I went down to Walmart and bought 2500 4.5mm BBs (for $4) and set to work printing my own ball bearings.
I first tried printing the inner part in two pieces, but they proved hard to glue together.  So I tried printing the inner part as one piece.  I didn't think I'd be able to get enough BBs into the channel for it to work.  I found that with pliers I can just muscle the last two or three BBs into the channel.  The plastic deforms a bit, but it returns to normal immediately.
With this design, it makes me wonder if some parts that are designed to fit a 608 bearing could just have the outer bearing feature included.  The you just print the inner part, add the BBs and grease and go!

The trick is to get your tolerances correct.  My Makerbot prints holes slightly undersized, so I increased the diameter of the inner hole a little.  Also, getting the size of the channel correct is key if you don't want a sloppy bearing.
I print these parts 4 at a time using the multiply feature.  The outer part really doesn't need much work, but the inner parts need some cleaning because the channel surface ends up a little bit messy when the nozzle goes from one part to the next.  Some sandpaper did the trick for me.
Adding the BBs isn't too difficult.  Just twist the inner part slightly and add as many BBs as you can.  I get 6 or 7 into the channel by hand.  Then, for the last two or three BBs, I use channel-lock pliers or vice grip pliers to just shove the BBs into the channel.  Make sure to wait for the plastic to completely cool first, otherwise the deformation might be permanent.
I added a bit of grease and am actually amazed how smooth and tight the bearing is.  Obviously it isn't sealed so I don't know how long it will last, but it seems to work great.

comments.text: I have found if I print the center in nylon (one piece at a time) on the finest settings %100 infill I can push the bbs right in no trouble and I am impressed as to how well they run, I used them to make some fidget spinners for my kids. I may have use for them in a robot project I'm working on as well, thanks for this design!

comments.text: This works amazingly well, using the method with printing it about 50% the way through then pausing to add BB's and finishing the print comes out really good.  It would be interesting if you added divots into the inner ring to allow for only something like 7 BB's to be evenly spaced across the ring yet spin in place and preventing the potential for binding that sometimes happens when the BB's are allowed to freely move around as they do now.

Stepper motor mount for the RigidBot. It has the following changes from the original RigidBot design:
1 - It is offset by 6mm to line up with the idler bearing when used with a 16 tooth pulley.
2 - It is designed to use M4x25 socket cap screws and M4 nuts (since the motor mount threads on my RigidBot came stripped).
3 - It has two gaskets printed in NinjaFlex and/or Polyflex for sound dampening. The flat gasket is 1mm thick, but you can rescale it to whatever thickness you like. You will need to mirror the part if using on the Y-axis. The black gasket on the left was printed in PolyFlex, the red gasket on the right in NinjaFlex. edit: Added another version of the mount, one without the flexible parts (I switched to this one to use with Astrosyn dampers). I used Taulman Bridge nylon, but it should work in other materials. This version will require support material to print. edit 2: Turns out the Astrosyn dampers tilted more than I liked under tension, so I switched to a new mount that merges the design from the first two versions of the mount (version 3).

comments.text: This is great, but don't you need an offset idler at the other end?  Otherwise, the belt will be at an angle, won't it?
comments.author: GeekDoc

comments.text: If used with a 16 tooth GT2 pulley the edge nearest the belt mount should remain parallel to the direction of travel.  The other side will be angled but that shouldn't matter since there isn't anything attached on that side.  That is assuming you don't change the size of the idler bearing, if you change that, that mount would need to be offset too.

author: kc7mgo

description.text:
This is a 3D printed base Vehicle, I was disappointed with what was available/quality of other projects so I created this with the goal that’s it’s easy for anyone to modify or add on to. Using duel stepper motors this tank is fully controllable and turns on a dime. Youtube Video of it in action
http://youtu.be/C18eJW3MO5c

Things required 1 Arduino of choice
2 Stepper Motor Drivers (I used Adafruit Motor Shield with two drivers built in)
2 Stepper Motors
4 Stepper motor Screws 5-8 mm in Length Optional Items
Adafruit Bluefruit shield (wireless control)
Lipo 3s 11.1 V battery Only 4 screws are required for the tank 2 Screws for each Stepper Motor
Use 1.75 mm filament for assemble of the tracks they should require being gently tapped in as the outer holes are smaller than the inner. What you need to print
I Printed these items at 15% fill .25 height
Time # Item
1h 2 12spoke Gears
1h 2 8spoke gears
2.5h 1 mainbodytank
5h 54 TankTreads
0h 54 20mm x 1.75 mm filament rivets I have supplied all original FreeCad Drawings
The default wheel spacing is 140mm if you make your own body
To make Additional Gears/Change the sizes
in FreeCad goto Macro and then C:/Program Files (x86)/FreeCAD0.13/Mod/PartDesign/Scripts
Here you will a script named Gear.py
the parameters you will need are EXAMPLE:
Number of Teeth 12 (This is the value you change)
Circular Pitch 16
Pressure Angle 4
Tooth Height Factor .5
Tooth Clearance .01
Tooth Lateral Clearance 1
Gear Width 6.0 This is the part that sucks the gear it created cannot be cut/Boolean so then you need to create circles and rectangles with chamfered ends (I used even numbers so I could just make one long rectangle then chamfer the ends then you can copy paste and just rotate them into order (warning large numbers of teeth take a long time to combine these do one at a time) For the Arduino Code Check the zip file and readme
The Arduino code uses Serial inputs to control the tank and controls both the tracks separately.

title: Customizer Push-me-pull-you Extruder Drive

description.text: I'm potentially faced with producing scads of copies of prints and need a way to increase productivity of the printer. This extruder drive uses a regular 'ol hobbed bolt and pushes two 1.75mm filaments simultaneously. It will be attached to a pair of these rocking awesome x-carriages: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:45883, each fitted with a 1.75mm x 0.35mm J-head hot end. The carriages will be placed on the x axis, splitting the build volume equally between the two hot ends. My thoughts are that I'll halve the x dimensions of the printer build volume in Cura, making plates of parts that will build in a 100mm x 200mm x-y space. Duplicate parts should be produced on the printer twice as fast as I've been able to in the past. This does work, at least with a single filament, which is all I can test with at the moment. The rub is that I only have a single J-head at the moment and I'm desperately hoping someone better equipped might want to help me out and test this thing...

02.13.13 - changed the Customizer code to only render extruder end, idlers and caps, the motor end is now an stl. Changed the motor end to have beefier rod mounts as I snapped the wimpy original ones off. Some other structural mods to the motor end to improve printing and strength. Several prints have now been produced and experience thus far is good. Plugged up the hobs and had to clean them out and printed idlers having a bit more spring stretch to try and combat that issue, will update as experience permits. The 1" x 9/32" (od) x 0.047" (wire diameter) springs on the one pictured work great with hard PLA but squish ABS too much. I'm looking for the right spring for ABS. Measure the distance from bolt head (the inside where a washer would go) to the center of the hob and enter this value for Cap To Hob in the Customizer. Enter your spring dimensions in the Customizer. In Customizer, render one each of Extruder end and Idlers and caps and print at 100% infill. Print gear_sun.stl, input_half.stl, output_half.stl, output_carrier.stl and planetgears.stl. There are two M3 nut traps in the interior of the extruder end where the hobbed bolt passes through. Carefully press an M3 nut into each before proceeding. Assemble the gearbox per http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:41876 using the hobbed bolt for the output shaft. Make sure all four M3 nuts are in the extruder end (four holes on the pedestal - nuts pressed into interior side) so that idlers and springs can be mounted. The extruder end requires:
3 each 608 bearings
2 each of M3 x 30mm screws, M3 nuts and M3 washers for mount-side spring mounts
2 each of M3 x 16mm screws and M3 nuts for idler-side spring mounts
2 each of M3 x 30mm screws and M3 washers (between idler and end) for idler pivots
2 each of M3 x 16mm screws and and M3 nuts for mounting in-out caps
2 each M4 nut for Bowden sheath lock
2 each 8mm diameter x 16mm smooth rod for idler shafts
1 each M8 nylon locking nut
2mm id x 4mm od PTFE (teflon) tubing for Bowden sheath 1) Put the 608 bearings and their shafts in the idler holders.
2) Push the spring ends into the idler holders and run the M3 x 16mm screws through them and tighten into the nuts (traps provided)
3) Use the 30mm M3 screws to attach the idler holders to their pivot points (the idler shaft is exposed) with a M3 washer placed between the extruder end and the idler holder
4) Put the M3 x 30mm screws through the other ends of the springs, spin on a nut and then a washer and thread the screws into their holes in the extruder end.
5) Push the PTFE tubing through the appropriate hole in the in-out caps (has the M4 nut trap in it
6) Thread the M4 nuts onto the ends of the 4mm PTFE tubing, trim and ream, make sure 1.75 mm filament can freely pass through
7) Affix the caps to the extruder end with M3 x 16mm screws. Take a picture and show me you built one!

comments.text: Very interesting design! I just had a midly similar idea, so I decided to poke around on Thingiverse and see what else I could find like it. My idea isn't for bowden extruders, so it will have to have 2 separate drive gears hobbed into the bolt.It will also include a rocker arm mechanism actuated by a 5V solenoid to select which filament is being driven, meaning it will only be able to extrude 1 filament at a time.

description.text:
Extruder based on the R3D Extruder I'm not able to find as a reference - but without most of its shortcommings
It's a single piece extruder with high pressure and very good filament guidance. It uses a Teflon insert to prevent the filament material from grinding into the extruder. The guide also helps having a steady and error-free extrusion and removes particles before they enter the hobbed bold.
It also features cable management using zip ties!
Last but not least a regular J-Head Nozzle can be mounted without any additional parts! Just put it in and use the two screws to tighten it.
Solidworks. It's a completely new construction based in R3Ds work!

This is a rather large chess set, suitable for putting on a coffee table or some other centerpiece.
The chess pieces follow the Staunton pattern.

description.text:
Though this has been addressed before:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1440
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4264
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4379 There wasn't a 2D representation that I could find easily for cutting on a laser cutter or paper cutter, so here it is!

I had trouble cutting cork sheet on my laser cutter but 2mm EVA foam (craft foam) worked great! Here's my settings I cut it on my 35W mini-18:
Speed: 90%
Power: 100%
Freq: 500 Hz Tip: You can install the Z axis gasket without removing the pulley by cutting a slit in the gasket. Though I used a laser cutter you can just as easily just print this design out and cut them with scissors or an hobby knife, or you could order some from me </shameless self promotion>:
http://builttospecstore.storenvy.com/

comments.text: I ordered these from your store and they work great!  Unfortunately, I was only able to put them on the X and Z axes.  The gap for the Y axis where I would install these on my MakerFarm i3v is way too small to fit one of these in there.  They work great and are priced right, would definitely recommend.

This is a replacement filter / grate for a InvisaFlow 4400 Flex Grate Downspout Filter I purchased from Amazon.com:
http://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B0061Q5DW2/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o09_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
Our dog ate the original filters, and I needed to replace them. The 3D printed parts worked great. I also created a deflector to attach to the inside of the upper portion of the downspout to deflect water towards the back of the filter instead of out through the opening.

1) print parts. I printed the "chevron" side down on the build plate and had the "vertical stripe" reinforcements bridge over the top of the chevrons. That worked well for me, but your mileage may vary.
2) use zip ties to attach to the original downspout filter

This is a very simple dial indicator holder for the XYZ Da Vinci 1.0 3D printer.
Preferably print the piece twice, so you can put one on top of the X carriage and the other one underneath, nicely gripping the dial indicator. It should fit tightly in the central hole (I had to file it a little). I'm also using two binder clips for extra stability when moving the dial indicator left and right.
I printed it at 0.3 layer height with 20% infill (the piece is thin so better make it a bit strong). Also add at least 3 top and bottom layers.

comments.text: It's a sheet of BuildTak, see http://www.buildtak.eu/ It works well, but IMO it's too expensive (considering shipping costs, etc) for what it lasts, which is not much. After printing a few times on the same area the plastic begins to develop some sort of bulges and holes which besides decreasing adherence, leave an ugly finish on the bottom of the prints. I'm probably going back to bare glass + glue stick when I run through all the BuildTak sheets I bought.
